question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Question 1-3 are short-answer
questions. Put your answer in the box provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answer as much as possible}. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct
answer placed in the box. \textbf{Show your work}, for part marks.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH101April2013Q1ab.jpg}
\caption{MATH101April2013Q1ab.jpg}
\end{figure}

Use the Trapezoidal Rule, with \emph{n} = 4, to estimate the area under
the graph between \emph{x} = 2 and \emph{x} = 6. Remember to simplify
your answer completely.
sols:
We proceed as suggested by the hint. First notice that

$\displaystyle \Delta x = (6-2)/4 = 1.$

Next, notice that

\begin{align*}
x_{0} &= 2 + 0\Delta x = 2\\
x_{1} &= 2 + 1\Delta x = 3\\
...&\\
x_{4} &= 2 + 4\Delta x = 6 
\end{align*}

Thus, figuring out the $f(x_{i})$ terms directly from the graph, we have

$T_4 = \frac12[3+(2)(8)+(2)(7)+(2)(6)+4] = \frac{49}2$
hints:
The Trapezoid Rule in full generality is

$T_{n} = \frac{\Delta x}{2} \Big(f(x_{0}) + 2f(x_{1}) + 2f(x_{2}) + ... + 2f(x_{n-1}) + f(x_{n}) \Big)$

where

$\Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

and

$\displaystyle x_{i} = a + i\Delta x$
